D.O. acknowledges the support of the China Scholarship Council. Zhirong Wang is the winner of China Youth Science and Technology Award, leader of Jiangsu Excellent Science and Technology Innovation Team and Jiangsu Six Talent Summit Innovation Team, has been working at Nanjing Tech University since 2005. From 2013 to 2014, he was a visiting professor at the University of Maryland, College Park, USA. His research interests include fire and explosion prevention and control, hazardous chemical safety, safety management engineering, urban and industrial safety, chemical safety, fire safety, etc. item Review Exploring the thermal stability of lithium-ion cells via accelerating rate calorimetry: A review Dongxu Ouyang a Mingyi Chen b Jingwen Weng c Kuo Wang a Jian Wang c ⁎ Zhirong Wang a ⁎ a College of Safety Science and Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 211816, Jiangsu, China College of Safety Science and Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 211816 Jiangsu China College of Safety Science and Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 211816, Jiangsu, China b School of Environment and Safety Engineering, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang 212013, Jiangsu, China School of Environment and Safety Engineering Jiangsu University Zhenjiang 212013 Jiangsu China School of Environment and Safety Engineering, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang 212013, Jiangsu, China c State Key Laboratory of Fire Science, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, 230026, Anhui, China State Key Laboratory of Fire Science University of Science and Technology of China Hefei, 230026 Anhui China State Key Laboratory of Fire Science, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, 230026, Anhui, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The accelerating rate calorimetry is universally applied to the multilevel safety evaluation of lithium-ion cells, which effectively guarantees cell safety and promotes the development of associated industries. Given the importance of lithium-ion cell safety, a comprehensive review on the thermal stability of lithium-ion cells investigated by accelerating rate calorimetry (ARC), is provided in the present work. The operating mechanism of ARC is discussed first, including the usage and the reaction kinetics. Besides that, the thermal stability of the cathode/anode materials at elevated temperatures is revealed by examining the impacts of some significant factors, i.e., the lithium content, particle size, material density, lithium salt, solvent, additive, binder and initial heating temperature. A comparison of the common cathode materials indicates that the presence of Mn and polyanion could significantly enhance the thermal stability of cathode materials, while the doping of Al also helps to restrain the reactivity. Except for their high capacity, some alloy materials demonstrate more competitive safety than traditional carbon anode materials. Furthermore, the thermal behaviors of full cells under abusive conditions are reviewed here. Due to the sensitivity of ARC to the kinetic parameters, a reaction kinetic modeling can be built on the basis of ARC profiles, to predict the thermal behaviors of cell components and cells. Herein, a short-circuit modeling is exampled. Keywords Accelerating rate calorimetry Electrode materials Full cells Safety Modeling 1 Introduction Since the first proposal by Sony in 1991, lithium-ion cells have been paid much attention, given their advantages such as a high energy density, low cost, stable performance and long life as an energy storage device [1,2]. With the approaching of new energy era, it is foreseeable that the use of lithium-ion cells will be more common and extensive. Nevertheless, challenges remain, despite the benefits from lithium-ion cell safety incidents being frequently reported, as these bring catastrophic damages to consumers and undermine the further progression of lithium-ion cells. Thereby, the safety issues of lithium-ion cells should not be overly neglected. To date, much research has been directed to reveal the thermal behaviors of cell components and full cells with the help of thermal calorimetry, e.g., C80 micro calorimetry, accelerating rate calorimetry (ARC), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), thermo gravimetric analyzer (TGA), and cone calorimetry [3–9]. In general, DSC and TGA are employed to demonstrate the thermal behaviors at the cell-component level, such as the stability of electrodes and electrolytes. C80 micro calorimetry is also used to analyse the thermal stability of cell materials, but it shows higher precision in comparison with DSC and TGA. Cone calorimetry is usually employed at the level of full cells and even battery packs to illustrate combustion behaviors such as the heat release rate, gas release rate, radiation heat flow, and mass loss rate. Compared to the above-mentioned thermal calorimetry, ARC shows better universality that is applicable to the multilevel safety evaluation of lithium-ion cells ranging from cell components, full cells, and battery packs. In addition, ARC is an adiabatic system; therefore the self-heating rate of a sample can be measured accurately during tests. ARC can also illustrate the evolution of gaseous products during tests by detecting the pressure. Moreover, the material in an ARC sample can be recovered and studied after testing. Benefiting from these properties, ARC devices have been widely used to investigate the thermal behaviors of samples. Among them, considerable researches were conducted to explore the thermal stability of lithium-ion cells and their components [10–18], which greatly improved the opinion on the safety issues of cells. Table 1 lists the application history of ARC in lithium-ion battery safety research. Nevertheless, there is a lack of a proper summary of these studies, which is unfavorable to the systematic understanding of lithium-ion cell safety from multiple levels. To fill in this gap, the current work provides a comprehensive review on the previous investigations regarding the thermal stability of lithium-ion cells using ARC. The first section is related to the operating mechanism of ARC including the description of the instrument and some of the reaction kinetic models considered by ARC. The second section describes the investigation into the thermal stability of the cathode materials. The third section demonstrates the investigation into the thermal stability of the anode materials. The fourth section concerns the thermal stability of full cells and modeling to predict full cell safety. It is hoped that this review could provide a comprehensive knowledge that is available about lithium-ion cells, concerning their thermal stability issues, and further contribute to the enhancement of lithium-ion cell safety. 2 Operating mechanism of the ARC 2.1 Description of instrument ARC was designed and manufactured as an instrument that could analyze the kinetic features of reactions as well as the heat they produced. It was first developed by the Dow Chemical Company but was subsequently commercialized by Columbia Scientific [25,26]. The ARC instrument’s basic working principle is to keep a sample in an adiabatic state once an exothermic reaction has been identified, so the heat from the reaction speeds up the reaction itself. The sample is mounted inside a chamber. The three heating zones of the chamber: the top, side and base, are each independently heated and monitored by thermo-couples. This chamber is surrounded by a substantial steel shell, which acts a barrier in the event of an explosion while the experiment is being conducted. Four microswitches on the shell must be engaged before the instrument can receive any heat. Besides that, the pressure sensors are also installed inside the chamber, to monitor the variations in the reacting system’s pressure. A pressure limiting valve is configured to automatically switch off the sensor when the pressure exceeds the limit, protecting the sensor from over-pressure damage. 2.1.1 Calibration The equipment is configured to regulate the calorimetry temperature to remain at an initial target temperature while in calibration mode. The heating rate is set by the user, typically at 10 °C min−1. The sample and calorimetry will eventually equilibrate to the same temperature. The thermo-couples however may measure different potentials. In order to compensate for this discrepancy, several measurements of the sample temperature are averaged. This averaged temperature is compared to the chamber temperature to determine an offset value in microvolts. This offset value, when added to the sample temperature produces the correct temperature. This offset is also used in subsequent runs to compensate for the small background drifts that occur because of the different voltage responses of the thermo-couples at the same temperature [27]. The offsets are evaluated from the initial set point temperature to the final set point temperature in 25 °C steps. 2.1.2 Heat-wait-search (HWS) mode Once the thermo-couple is calibrated, the instrument is ready to proceed regarding a measurement. In general, the ARC instrument is operated in the heat-wait-search (HWS) mode, and the corresponding procedure is shown in Fig. 1 . For every new sample, two standard measurements are generally preferred. At first, a sample is heated from room temperature to the initial set point temperature at a fixed heating rate. After letting the temperature equilibrate (for 2 h), the ARC instrument searches for a minimum temperature change (the threshold value is defined by the user in °C min−1). The system enters exotherm mode if the observed temperature rate exceeds this limit. Since there is no heat exchange between the sample and its surroundings in this mode, it is possible to detect the temperature and thus track the heat energy of the reactions. The system switches back to heat mode, where the temperature is raised by a temperature step, if there is no self-heating higher than or equals to this threshold. The HWS mode keeps running until either the final set point temperature (Tf ) is reached or the self-heating rate surpasses the critic (the maximum self-heating rate). After then, compressed air is introduced into the calorimetry chamber to totally shut down the ARC instrument and cool the system. 2.2 Probing reaction kinetics with ARC According to chemical kinetics, we know that [28] (1) d α d t = k ( T ) × f ( α ) where (2) k ( T ) = A × e - E a k B T α is the concentration of the reactant, A is the frequency factor, E a is the activation energy of the process, k B is Boltzmann’s constant and T is the temperature. During an ARC experiment, the self-heating rate is given by (3) d T d t = h C × d α d t where h is the reaction heat and C is the sample’s specific heat. h/C corresponds to the temperature rise, ΔT, during the exotherm process because (4) ∫ 0 ∞ d T d t d t = Δ T And (5) ∫ 0 ∞ h C d α d t d t = h C Δ α = h C Thus, (6) Δ T = h C The following equation is employed to determine the activation energy of the self-heating process (7) d T d t = Δ T k ( T ) f ( α ) Taking the natural logarithm of both sides, a linear line can be plotted for ln(dT/dt) versus 1/T. And then the activation energy, E a of a reaction can be obtained through the linear slope. Referring back to Eq. (1), the reaction model f(α) can be derived from a number of physical situations, and examples are displayed in Table 2 , where the zero order, first order and second order reaction models are included. Fig. 2 shows the hypothetical self-heating rates versus temperature when the reaction order, n equals 0, 1 and 2, respectively. As can be seen, a reaction that is independent of the concentration of the reactant (n = 0) self-heats indefinitely. A reaction that is dependent on the concentration of the reactant has a heating rate that eventually goes to zero when the reactant is depleted. Thereby, the ARC profile deviates to the right of the zero-order line, and the heating rate eventually slows when the reaction proceeds to completion. The morphologies of the ARC profiles roughly stay the same as the reaction order increases, but the ARC trace deviates farther from the zero-order line, as exhibited by the curve of the second order. In addition to the nth-order reaction kinetics, there are some other kinetics considered in the ARC measurements. Fig. 3 (a) shows the typical profiles that can be obtained in a reaction governed by diffusion [dα/dt = k(−ln(1 − α))−1]. The transport of one or more reactant species to or a product from a reaction interface controls the overall rate of these reactions. Since the ARC profile has a high initial self-heating rate that soon falls and is followed by an area with a roughly constant rising slope, it may be clearly distinguished from the n th-order reaction kinetics. Fig. 3(b) shows the typical profiles for a reaction governed by power law kinetics (dα/dt = kαn, n>0). When the initial growth of nuclei is slower than the constant value that is subsequently acquired, power law kinetics are obtained [29]. The ARC profile is located in the left (above) of the ‘Arrhenius line’ (the dashed line which can be used to calculate the reaction activation energy by Arrhenius law) indicating that the reaction is accelerated by the presence of the product. This is shown by the self-heating rate rising quickly at first, then leveling off to have a roughly constant upward slope that lasts until the reaction is finished. The ARC profile is easily distinguished from those previously shown. Fig. 3(c) illustrates the typical profiles for an Avrami-Erofeev reaction [dα/dt = k(1 − α)(−ln(1 − α))2/3]. The Avrami-Erofeev formulas have been discovered to describe many solid phase decompositions, phase transformations, recrystallizations and reactions between solids [29]. Their ARC profiles are above the ‘Arrhenius line’ to the left, with a growing self-heating rate that gradually reduces as the reactant depletes. 3 Investigation on the thermal stability of cathode materials Lithium was first introduced into the positive electrode of cells with the development of the lithium cobaltate (LCO) cathode material, which was the earliest commercialized layered cathode material of lithium-ion cells. This led to the application and development of a negative electrode free of lithium and increased the operating voltage of cells [30]. Generally, LCO materials have a theoretical specific capacity of around 270 mA h g−1. During usage, the specific capacity is about 145 mA h g−1 when it is charged to 4.2 V (vs. Li/Li+), and when under 4.5 V (vs. Li/Li+) it can be as high as 170 mA h g−1. In order to further improve the capacity of LCO materials, researchers have conducted extensive studies on the degradation mechanism, doping and coating of LCO materials [31,32]. Currently, LCO cathode materials still play an important role in the 3C-products industry, though drawbacks such as a relatively low energy density and poor safety limit their prospect; therefore, they are gradually being replaced by other cathode materials [33,34]. Further, the spinel-structure lithium manganate oxide (LMO) cathode material was proposed by Goodenough’s team in 1983. Despite having a theoretical capacity that is just approximately half that of LCO (148 mA h g−1), its reversible specific capacity is fine [35]. The poor cycling performance and storage performance under high-temperature environments, which are generally caused by the dissolution of Mn element, the decomposition of electrolytes and the Jahn-Teller effect, have hindered the large-scale applications of LMO materials [36]. To improve the performance of LMO materials, researchers have tried a variety of methods such as reducing specific surface area, metal cation doping, oxide coating, etc. [35,37]. Among them, the doping of partial Mn by Al has made great progress. A novel family of lithium insertion materials based on theolivine-structure lithium iron phosphate (LFP) cathode material was described by Padhi et al.in 1997 [38]. When properly manufactured, LFP has an exceptionally flat working voltage of 3.5 V versus lithium and a rechargeable capacity of 170 mA h g−1 [39,40]. Additionally, compared to other cathode materials, LFP cathode materials have better safety properties and are less prone to thermal runaway. However, since LFP has limited conductivity, there is a relatively low movement of the lithium ions [41]. Beyond that, most commercialized LFP powder particles have a tap density of 1.0 g cm−3, which is smaller than that of other cathode powders. The lower operating voltage and smaller density result in the relatively low energy density of LFP. Some countermeasures, e.g., replacing the iron in LFPwith other trivalent transitionmetal ions, surface carbon coating, polyaniondoping and the nanocrystallization of materials, were proposed to increase the operating voltages to over 4 V or decrease the density and further increase the energy density of LFP materials [42–45]. In a word, LFP modification will continue to be a research area of interest. One of the primary concerns of researchers is how to improve the electrochemical performance of LFP while retaining a high level of safety. Lithium nickel manganese cobalt oxide (NMC) ternary layered cathode material was first proposed by Lu et al. [46], which was derived from LCO cathode materials by modifying the Ni, Mn and Co content. Ni can increase capacity, Mn is in charge of maintaining the cathode materials’ structural stability and avoiding cell capacity decline, while Co plays a significant influence in the electrical conductivity of cells [47,48]. With the rapid development of electric vehicles, NMC materials have received a lot of attention due to their great capacity; meanwhile, NMC materials with a higher Ni content are gradually replacing those with a lower Ni content, due to the lower price and higher capacity. Whereas, cell safety is greatly compromised with an increase in Ni content [49]. The content of Ni in NMC materials has increased gradually, from NMC111 to NMC532 and NMC622, but it is still unable to satisfy the present demand for a high capacity and cheap cost. Therefore, the NMC811 material has been given lots of focus in recent years, but its extremely high reactivity with the electrolyte also brings serious safety risks [50]. Similar to NMC materials, lithium nickel cobalt aluminate oxide (NCA) ternary layered material was also derived from LCO positive electrode materials by modifying the Ni, Co and Al content. Within, the Ni and Co components are used to boost the capacity and electrical conductivity, respectively. The Al addition is mostly used to stabilize the lattice structures and prevent collapse during cycle. Due to their equivalent operating voltage, high energy density, and ideal features for practical applications, NCA materials are now thought to be among the most alluring materials [51], particularly for the commercial success of LiNi0.80Co0.15Al0.05O2 cathode materials. Rapid capacity fading during cycling, which results from the mix of Li/Ni cations, is the remaining issue for NCA materials [52]. Due to the comparable radii of Ni2+ and Li+, Ni2+ may easily infiltrate the lithium layer, which causes capacity loss and a heat hazard. Several pieces of research were published recently on methods to increase the stability of NCA materials [53–55]. These researches mostly relied on cationic doping to stop Ni2+ from migrating to the Li+ site in Ni-rich cathode materials. In addition, doping in the Li+ intercalation site is another crucial tactic for minimizing structural disorientation. The most recognized dopants that can be included in the Li+ site are Mg and Na. Finally, to decrease the cost of conventional cathode materials and further increase the energy density, Li-rich materials have become popular recently [56–60]. Li-rich layered oxides are structurally made up of a layered Li2MnO3 component and a LiMO2 (where M is mostly Mn, Ni and Co) component, i.e., xLiMO2·(1 − x)Li2MnO3. A suitable two-dimensional conduction channel for lithium ions is provided by the alternating-layer arrangement between Li2MnO3 and LiMO2 [61]. Lithium extraction and concomitant oxygen removal from the Li2MnO3 component allow Li-rich layered cathode materials to demonstrate discharge capacities larger than 250 mA h g−1 at high working voltages up to 4.8 V, in contrast to ordinary stacked LiMO2 oxides. A specific capacity greater than 300 mA h g−1 can even be attained by optimising the precursor and synthesis process [62]. Nevertheless, some shortcomings like a high irreversible capacity and poor rate performance limit the application of Li-rich materials. But it is certain that the ultra-high specific capacity and low cost of Li-rich materials will still attract a lot of focus during the development of cathode materials. 3.1 Effect of lithium content on the thermal stability of cathode materials During charging/discharging, lithium ions shift between the cathode and anode via the electrolyte, while the electrons move by the external circuit. Therefore, the state of charge (SOC) of a cell is affected by the lithium content within the electrodes. The higher the SOC, the lower the lithium content within the cathode will be. Nevertheless, the potential of cathode materials ascends with the removal of lithium ions, which may further decrease the thermal stability of cathode materials in the electrolytes. As one of the pioneers of thermal stability research on electrode materials, Richard [21] conducted considerable investigations to illustrate the reactivity between LCO powders and electrolytes at elevated temperatures. Fig. 4 (a) shows the self-heating profiles for LCO materials with different lithium contents in the LiPF6 EC:DEC (33:67) electrolytes. These LCO materials were charged to four different potentials: 4.2 V (Li0.45CoO2), 4.3 V (Li0.4CoO2), 4.4 V (Li0.35CoO2) and 4.5 V (Li0.27CoO2). As shown, self-heating in the 4.2 and 4.3 V samples starts at around 140 °C and has roughly the same intensity up to 170 °C. The self-heating in the 4.4 and 4.5 V samples is not as strong, but it is detected earlier, at 100 °C for the 4.5 V samples and at 130 °C for the 4.4 V samples. The earlier appearance of self-heating reveals the decreased thermal stability of the highly charged LCO materials. Similar results are also illustrated in the case of LMO materials [21]. With the removal of lithium, LCO and LMO materials are more unstable, so they are more likely to decompose and release oxygen, then react with the electrolyte. Hereafter, Wang et al. [5] researched the thermal stability of three types of cathode materials (LCO, NMC111 and Li(Ni0.8Co0.15Al0.05)O2) with different cut-off potentials (4.2 and 4.4 V) using ARC, as shown in Fig. 4(b) and (c). They claimed that the temperature at which cathode-electrolyte reactions resulted in thermal runaway in full cells was represented by a self-heating rate of 0.2 °C min−1 (in the ARC samples). Apparently, all the materials reach the self-heating rate of 0.2 °C min−1 at a lower temperature when charged to 4.4 V instead of 4.2 V. This indicates the decreased thermal stability of these three cathode materials with decreasing lithium contents. Similar studies were also performed by Ma and Huang et al. [50,63], as shown in Fig. 4(d) and (e), in which NMC series cathode materials (NMC111, NMC442, NMC532, NMC622 and NMC811) were selected and charged to differed cut-off potentials (4.1, 4.2, 4.3 and 4.4 V in Fig. 4d and 4.2, 4.4, 4.5 and 4.7 V in Fig. 4e). As can be seen, the critical temperatures when the self-heating rate reaches 0.2 °C min−1 decrease as the decline of the lithium content within the NMC series materials, except for NMC811, which has a reactivity that is the worst among all the NMC series materials such that the effect of the lithium content is not obviously exhibited. As the lithium content within the NMC series materials decreases, Ni2+ is oxidized to unstable Ni3+ and Ni4+, and Co3+ is oxidized to Co4+, which mostly contributes to the aggravated reactivity of the NMC series materials [65]. Besides that, with the extraction of lithium, the active oxygen species such as O2−, O−, O2 2− in NMC can be more easily oxidized to form oxygen and further combust the electrolyte to release heat [66]. With the further decline of the lithium content in cathode materials, i.e., by an overcharge, the profiles become more complicated. Maleki et al. [64] explored the reactivity between Sn-doped LCO materials and electrolytes, where five SOCs (50%, 100%, 125%, 150% and 200%) were contained. The corresponding ARC profiles are shown in Fig. 4(f). Similarly, exothermic reactions appear earlier with an increase in SOC. It should be noted that a series of new exothermic peaks occur from ∼50 to ∼150 °C for the overcharged cells, which is attributed to the thermal breakdown of some byproducts formed during overcharge at elevated temperatures. That is, overcharge greatly exacerbates the reactivity of LCO materials at elevated temperatures. 3.2 Effect of particle size on the thermal stability of cathode materials As is well-known, particle size (specific surface area) as one of the most important properties of cathode materials, significantly impacts the performance of lithium-ion cells. Meanwhile, it may also bring effects on the thermal stability of the cathode materials, which is associated with the reaction mechanism between the cathode materials and electrolytes, as well as the characteristics of the cathode materials. Jiang [67] investigated the reactivity between LCO materials with different particle sizes and electrolytes at elevated temperatures by an ARC. The samples labeled LCO (1), LCO (2) and LCO (3) possessed particle sizes of 0.8, 2.0 and 5.0 μm, respectively. Fig. 5 (a) and (b) show the ARC profiles for the three samples at the EC/DEC solvent and 1 M LiPF6 EC/DEC electrolyte, respectively. As can be seen, the sample LCO (1) exhibits the lowest onset temperature (110 °C) at the ethylcarbonate/diethyl carbonate (EC/DEC) solvent and the worst thermal stability among the three samples. The samples LCO (2) and LCO (3) have the same onset temperature of 150 °C and show similar self-heating behaviors. In general, LCO materials occur phase changes and decompose to release oxygen at elevated temperatures. An LCO sample with a smaller particle size has a shorter oxygen diffusion path, a greater oxygen release rate, and a larger area of contact with the EC/DEC solvent. This further causes the higher reactivity of LCO with a smaller particle size in the EC/DEC. Again, LCO (1) with a particle size of 0.8 μm shows the worst thermal stability with the 1 M LiPF6 EC/DEC electrolyte. The self-heating rate for LCO (2) is almost double that of LCO (3) between 170 and 210 °C, likely due to its smaller particle size. Similar phenomena also appear in the case of LMO materials [21], where the larger surface area greatly raises the self-heating rate of the LMO samples charged to 4.2 and 4.3 V in the electrolyte. For the LMO material with a high surface area, more oxygen could be released, so the combustion of the electrolytes would be more severe. Furthermore, Jiang et al. [68] explored the effect of particle size on the thermal stability of LFP materials. Fig. 5(c) demonstrates the thermal stability results for 100 mg of delithiated LFP with particle sizes of 3, 7 and 15 μm in 100 mg of EC/DEC solvent at elevated temperatures. However, the shape of the features of the curves for the three samples is almost identical, which is different from that of LCO and LMO results. This can be explained by the fact that the exotherm of LFP is caused by a solid–solid phase transition of FePO4 that is not affected by the surface area of LFP materials. Similar phenomena also occur for NMC111 (as shown in Fig. 5d). Jiang et al. [69] synthesized their NMC111 samples at ambient temperatures of 900, 1000 and 1100 °C, with primary particle sizes of 0.2, 0.8 and 8 μm obtained, respectively. However, the NMC111 sample prepared at 900 °C shows the highest thermal stability and no substantial exothermic signal until 210 °C, followed by those prepared at 1000 and 1100 °C. Obviously, the surface of the NMC111 sample prepared at 1100 °C is much more reactive than the other samples, even if its specific surface area is much lower. The excess Co within NMC111 could be present at the surface of the particles and be responsible for the poor stability of the higher-temperature samples. 3.3 Effect of material density on the thermal stability of cathode materials In order to design cells with higher capacity, many factors have to be considered. Among them, electrode dimensions such as thickness, length, density and porosity play a crucial role in the performance and capacity of commercial lithium-ion cells. It is generally known that thick and dense electrodes are needed for high-capacity cells, and thin and porous electrodes are needed for high-power cells [70]. However, denser cathode materials, i.e., materials with a higher density may demonstrate worse thermal stability at elevated temperatures. Kim et al. [71] pressed their NCA materials with a calendar roller with pressures of 0, 1020 and 2078 atm to obtain materials with different densities. After that, they explored the reactivity of these materials using an ARC instrument, the corresponding ARC profiles are shown in Fig. 6 . Thermal runaway occurs in all the NCA samples; however, the self-heating rate of the exothermic reactions between 150 and 220 °C increases with the increasing electrode density. Besides that, the sample with a higher density reaches the critic (20 °C min−1) earlier than those with a lower density, and the initial exothermic peaks also increase as the material density increases. These results suggest that cathode materials with a higher density exhibit lower thermal stability. Kim et al. declared that this was caused by the fewer electrolytes within the denser NCA materials. When the materials were pressed tightly, it would be harder to absorb electrolytes, namely less LiPF6. As is known, LiPF6 in the electrolyte suppresses the reaction rate of NCA materials because the polymeric reaction products created by the decomposition of LiPF6 form on the cathode material surface at an elevated temperature and hinder the release of oxygen from the cathode materials (see Section 3.4.1). Consequently, a more severe reactivity was illustrated by the cathode materials with a higher density. To date, work concerning the relationship between thermal stability and material density is still rare, more investigations should be conducted to verify the consequence of Kim et al., and obtain a more comprehensive knowledge about the effect of material density on the safety. 3.4 Effect of electrolytes on the thermal stability of cathode materials 3.4.1 Effect of lithium salt In general, the electrolytes used in lithium-ion cells are based on an organic solvent, with some dissolved lithium salt. Additionally, various types of additives are added to enhance the performance of lithium-ion cells, including cycling characteristics, safety, and so on. At present, LiPF6 as the most successful lithium salt, is widely applied in lithium-ion cells and it significantly influences the thermal stability of cathode materials [72–74]. Fig. 7 (a) depicts the thermal stability results of 100 mg of EC/DEC (33/67) electrolyte with varied concentrations of LiPF6 at elevated temperatures. There is little or even no self-heating demonstrated by the sample with low LiPF6 concentration (0–0.5 M). As the concentration of LiPF6 in the EC/DEC rises, the electrolyte shows stronger self-heating which is attributed to the decomposition of LiPF6 and the following reactions with the solvent at elevated temperatures, see Eqs. (8)–(10) [75]. (8) LiPF 6 → LiF + PF 5 (9) PF 5 + H 2 O → 2HF + PF 3 O (10) n C 3 H 4 O 3 → HF - - CH 2 - CH 2 - O - - n + n CO 2 Once LiPF6 decomposes, the generated PF5 is present in the solvent at an elevated temperature. Water, a component of the electrolyte that is an impurity, interacts with the PF5. Under the catalysis of HF, the decomposition and polymerization of the EC solvent will be induced to generate polymer. Since the self-heating rates of LiPF6 in the EC/DEC are generally low, any self-heating of the cathode should not be significantly impacted by the electrolyte’s self-heating. Further, MacNeil et al. [75] performed heating experiments to explore the impact of LiPF6 concentration in the EC/DEC (33/67) on the thermal stability of LCO, see Fig. 7(b). In situations with low molarities of LiPF6, the self-heating rate rises with temperature extremely quickly. It is clear that there is a significant suppression in the pace of the combustion process as the molarity rises over 0.5 M. In other words, the addition of salt significantly reduces the rate at which the solvent burns up when oxygen from the cathode is present. MacNeil et al. argued that it was the result of the generated polymer (Eq. (10), deposited on the surface of LCO, which impeded any self-heating reaction. The amount of the polymer that was produced increased and the oxygen release was further restricted when the concentration of LiPF6 in the organic solvent rose. The solvent burned more cautiously as a result of the oxygen being released more gradually. The temperature rose less abruptly as a result of the slower combustion, allowing for more effective heat dissipation. In conclusion, the addition of the LiPF6 salt renders the LCO materials safer than when the organic solvent is present alone, and this result may help in the development of safer lithium-ion cells. Moreover, LiPF6 as the lithium salt added into the carbonate solvent is more competitive in LCO-based lithium-ion cells from the perspective of safety, in comparison with some other salts such as LiBF4 and lithium bis(oxalate)borate (LiBOB). As shown in Fig. 8 , LiPF6 salt illustrates a more depressed self-heating rate than LiBF4 and LiBOB. Both LiBF4 and LiBOB are much more thermally stable than LiPF6 so that they do not react with the solvent to form polymeric species. As discussed above, these polymeric species enhance the thermal stability of the electrode by coating the LCO particles, hindering the oxygen release and the consequent solvent combustion. In addition, similar results are also illustrated in the cases of NCA and lithium nickelate (LNO) cathode materials [67,76]. Therefore, it is recommended to apply LiPF6 as the lithium salt in LCO-, NCA- or LNO-based lithium-ion cells from the perspective of safety. However, contrary phenomena are demonstrated in LFP and LMO cathode materials [68,77]. The thermal stability of LFP cathode materials in the EC/DEC solvent containing salts of LiPF6 and LiBOB was researched by Jiang et al. [68], see Fig. 9 (a). The thermal stability of delithiated LFP deteriorates with the addition of LiPF6 to the EC/DEC solvent, and the onset temperature is around 190 °C for all three samples (LFP samples produce an exothermic reaction when the temperature is higher than 300 °C in the EC/DEC solvent), which results from the exotherm of the LiPF6 salt since LiPF6 is not thermally stable at elevated temperatures. The generated polymer does not work here because the solvent does not combust in the case of LFP. Hence, Jiang et al. recommended LiBOB as the lithium salt in LFP-based lithium-ion cells. On the other hand, the onset temperature of an exotherm greater than 0.02 °C min−1 for the LMO samples decreases with the increasing concentration of LiPF6 (see Fig. 9b). The amount of HF increases with the increase in LiPF6, which makes it harder for Mn to dissolve into the electrolyte. This may prevent MnO products from building up on the surface of the particles, allowing the solvent oxidation to proceed more quickly than it would without salt. Similar results also occurred in the case of NMC materials and Kim et al. [76] declared that this phenomenon (higher LiPF6 concentration leads to higher reactivity) fit for all cathode materials containing the Mn element. 3.4.2 Effect of solvent In the early 1990 s, graphite was successfully employed as the anode in lithium-ion cells after the electrolyte solution based on EC was established [78,79]. The reason for this was that the EC’s decomposition products created an efficient protective film (solid electrolyte interphase layers, SEI layers) on the exterior graphite surfaces, allowing for the insertion of lithium while preventing solvent co-intercalation [78,80]. Since EC is a solid at ambient temperature, it is typically combined with low-viscosity solvents to boost ionic conductivity. Examples of such solvents include ethers, such as dimethoxyethane (DME), and alkyl carbonates, such as dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and DEC. The solvent, which makes up the majority of the electrolyte, may have an impact on the thermal stability of lithium-ion cells. In general, pure organic solvents do not exhibit any obvious exothermic or endothermic activity during the heating of ARC. Therefore, totally flat curves (temperature versus time) are demonstrated under the HWS mode, as depicted in Fig. 10 (a and b). Fig. 10(c) shows the effect of solvents on the thermal stability of LCO materials, in which the self-heating rate profiles of LCO with/without the EC/DMC solvent added are included. Apparently, the reactivity of LCO is greatly exacerbated in the presence of solvents. The sample with solvents begins to self-heat at around 130 °C and proceeds rapidly to the end of the self-heating rate (20 °C min−1). As for the dry sample, it appears a small exotherm begins at about 140 °C. The ARC instrument continues its HWS procedure after tracking this first exothermic event but finds no sustained exothermic occurrences until 240 °C and the self-heating rate does not reach the critic. The existence of solvents brings about the combustion of the solvent with the released oxygen, see Eqs. (11)–(13) [75]. In other words, the presence of flammable solvents deteriorates the thermal reactivity of the cathode materials that would decompose and release oxygen at elevated temperatures. (11) Li x CoO 2 → x LiCoO 2 + ( 1 - x ) Co + ( 1 - x ) O 2 (12) 2 C 3 H 4 O 3 (EC ) + 5 O 2 → 6 CO 2 + 4 H 2 O (13) 2 C 5 H 10 O 3 (DEC ) + 12 O 2 → 10 CO 2 + 10 H 2 O Referring to Eq. (6), the temperature rise in the sample can be described as Δ T = h C tot , where h is the total heat released from the combustion reactions and C tot is the total heat capacity of the sample determined by the cathode material, solvent and ARC tube. Therefore, when the mass of the cathode material is constant, adjusting the mass ratio between the cathode material and solvent influences the final temperature rise in the sample. Fig. 11 depicts the thermal reactivity results for 100 mg of LCO with 100, 150 and 200 mg of EC/DEC solvent, where the temperature rise in the sample decreases with the increasing solvent mass. This is the result of the constant heat that is released and the increased heat capacity. Due to the inherent combustion risks of traditional organic solvents, ionic liquids have been proposed as alternative electrolyte solvents for lithium-ion cells during the past decades [81–86] because of their alleged benefits of non-flammability, no detectable vapour pressure up to 200 °C, high chemical and thermal stability, high ionic conductivity, low toxicity, and, in some cases, hydrophobicity. Using an ARC instrument, Wang et al. [87] investigated the reactivity between three ionic liquids, i.e., 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(flfluorosulfonyl)imide (EMI-FSI), 1-Ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(triflfluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (EMI-TFSI), 1-butyl-2,3-dimethylimidazolium bis(triflfluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (BMMI-TFSI), and charged LCO materials, by comparing it the reactivity of traditional organic solvents with the same cathode material. Fig. 12 shows the self-heating rate versus temperature for 100 mg of LCO and 100 mg of EMI-FSI, EMI-TFSI, and BMMI-TFSI. Obviously, all three types of ionic liquids exhibit greater heat stability compared to conventional organic solvents when LCO is used. The corresponding effect of ionic liquids on the safety of other cathode materials is still waiting to be verified. 3.4.3 Effect of additive With the development of lithium-ion cells, some novel electrolyte additives such as vinylene carbonate (VC), ethylene sulfate (DTD), trimethylene sulfate (TMS) and flfluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) have been proposed to extend cell life, minimize impedance rise, reduce gas generation, etc. [88–90]. It is widely recognized that electrolyte additives are applied to boost the stability of the SEI layer by being preferably reduced or by combining with the SEI’s final products to generate a stable and insoluble film on the anode material’s surface [91]. Similarly, the surface films on the cathode material are known to be impacted by electrolyte additions. Since a surface coating that forms on the electrode material has a significant impact on the reactivity between the electrodes and the electrolytes, it is conceivable that additives have an impact on the electrode materials’ thermal stability. Ma et al. [92] conducted a set of testing to explore the influence of eight promising additives (prop-1-ene-1,3-sultone (PES), methylene methanedisulfonate (MMDS), DTD, TMS, VC, tris(trimethylsilyl) phosphate (TTSP), propylene sulfate (PLS), and tris(trimethylsilyl) phosphite (TTSPi)) on the reactivity of NMC111 materials with electrolytes. Fig. 13 (a) shows the ARC results for 94 mg of delithiated NMC111 reacting with 30 mg of electrolytes containing 2 wt% of selected additives. Among them, 2% VC caused the self-heating rate to be somewhat greater than that of the control electrolytes between 200 and 250 °C. MMDS, PES and TTSPi produced a small enhancement in thermal stability compared to the control, by postponing the thermal runaway temperature by ∼10 °C. While DTD, TMS, PLS and TTSP brought little impact compared with the control electrolyte. A similar conclusion was also proposed by Kim et al. [76]: the thermal stability of NMC111 decreased gently with the addition of VC, which still fit the case of NCA materials. Moreover, they found that the addition of succinon-itrile (SN) could somewhat aggravate the reactivity of NMC materials, while decreasing that of NCA materials, see Fig. 13(b). Combing through all the related research [63,76,92,93], it can be found that the impact of additives on the thermal stability of cathode materials is relatively minor compared with that of some other factors such as lithium salt and solvent. The corresponding impacts brought by additives on the anode materials are even more evident, which will be discussed in Section 4.4.3. As stated before, additives influence lithium-ion cells by affecting the formation of SEI layers, that might be the reason why the additives impact more significantly on the anode materials than the cathode materials. 3.5 Effect of binder on the thermal stability of cathode materials The binder is mixed with electrode materials to hold the electrode particles together and to the current collector. It is a polymer adhering to the surface that it contacts. The choice of binder perturbs the interface between the electrodes and the electrolytes, so it may affect the safety of lithium-ion cells. So far, the most typical binder used in lithium-ion cells is polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF). Jiang [67] researched the thermal stability of rinsed LCO materials with a 7% PVDF binder at elevated temperatures by an ARC instrument. Fig. 14 shows the corresponding ARC profile. There is no obvious exothermic reaction exhibited. The mini-exothermic self-heating peaks at 170 and 270 °C should be attributed to the reaction between LCO materials and the small amount of residual electrolytes after rinsing. That is, the LCO materials do not react significantly with PVDF. Referring back to Fig. 5, where panel (c) demonstrates the self-heating rate curves of LFP materials with/without a PVDF binder in 100 mg of EC/DMC solvent. A comparison reveals that the second exothermic peak beginning around 320 °C only appears in the presence of a PVDF binder, indicating it may be induced by PVDF in some way. Nevertheless, the exothermic behavior caused by PVDF is very minor, so it does not greatly impact the whole process. In summary, the effect of a binder on the thermal stability of cathode materials is relatively slight, which is comparable to that of additives. 3.6 Effect of initial heating temperature on the thermal stability of cathode materials The initial temperature of the ARC instrument is usually set by users, to distinguish reactions more accurately. When an ARC measurement starts, the sample is heated to an initial temperature first, and then the HWS process starts. Therefore, the choice of initial temperature greatly impacts the self-heating profiles and the duration of measurements. Once the reaction of a sample is induced, the self-heating rate can be expressed as follows, by combining Eqs. (1)−(3) (the details of the parameters are shown in Section 2.2). (14) d T d t = h C A × e - E a / k B T f ( α ) As the initial temperature increases, it is apparent that the sample exhibits a higher initial self-heating rate, see Fig. 15 (a) where different initial temperatures including 150, 160, 170, 180 and 185 °C are demonstrated. Taking the natural logarithm on both sides of Eq. (14) produces. (15) ln d T d t = ln h C A + ln ( f ( α ) ) - E a k B T Initially, α equals one; therefore, Eq. (15) can be expressed as (16) ln d T d t = ln h C A - E a k B T Based on Eq. (16), a plot of the natural logarithm of the self-heating rate against 1/T can be depicted, as shown in Fig. 15(b). Obviously, the initial points can be fit as a straight line, the ‘Arrhenius line’, with a slope that is connected to the activation energy and an intercept that is related to the frequency factor. In the end, the activation energy of 4.2 V LCO reacting with electrolytes can be calculated as 1.7 eV. Moreover, the phenomenon of the ‘Arrhenius line’ fits all the reactants with different initial temperatures when they are heated by an ARC instrument, which can be further used to compare the thermal stability of various cathode materials [67]. 3.7 Thermal stability comparison of different cathode materials Observing the developing history of cathode materials for lithium-ion cells, it is a process seeking higher capacity and better safety; although, there is a trade-off between capacity and safety. Table 3 lists the developing history of some of the main cathode materials of commercial lithium-ion cells. To date, LCO as the earliest commercialized cathode material, exhibits a very poor thermal stability, as obvious exothermic reactions occur at around 140 °C when it is charged to 4.2 V [20]. The followed LMO material illustrates much better safety than LCO, which may be attributed to its lower specific capacity [67]. Most phosphate-based cathode materials possess excellent thermal stability such as LFP and LiV2(PO4)3, which have exothermic reactions with electrolytes that appear at up to 300 °C and the released heat is comparatively minor due to the existence of stable P–O bonds [40,94–98]. But their low energy density caused by the low voltage plateau hinders their usage; therefore, some improvements are proposed, e.g., LiMn0.8Fe0.2PO4 and LiVPO4F to enhance the energy density while maintaining the stability [99–104]. The appearance of ternary cathode materials such as NMC and NCA increases the specific capacity of the cathode materials to higher than 200 mA h g−1; at the same time, their safety is generally better than that of LCO. However, as the ratio of Ni within ternary cathode materials increases, the reactivity of the cathode materials is greatly aggravated. NMC811 can even appear as an obvious exotherm at around 120 °C [50]. Recently, Ni-rich cathode materials have attracted a lot of attention [105–107]. LNO starts to release heat at approximately 160 °C, which is similar to the behavior of NCA [71,108]. Meanwhile, Li-rich cathode material is also becoming popular owing to its low cost and high capacity [109–111]. The thermal stability of LCO materials was stated above. They release oxygen at elevated temperatures to combust electrolytes and release a great deal of heat. Therefore, the safety of LCO materials is not convincing. To enhance the thermal stability of LCO, researchers have tried considerable methods, such as the doping of Al, Mg, Mn, Co etc., [112–114]. Zhou et al. [112] investigated the impact of Al or Mg substitution on the thermal stability of LCO by using an ARC instrument. Fig. 16 (a) shows the ARC profiles of 100 mg of delithiated LiCo1 − z M z O2 (z = 0, 0.05, 0.1; M = Al or Mg, 4.3 V) reacting with 30 mg of 1 M LiPF6 EC:DEC. As seen, the substitution of Al or Mg in LCO aids in reducing the exothermic interaction between the charged LCO and electrolytes. Between them, Al substitution is far more effective in enhancing the stability of LCO than Mg substitution, which is the result of the much larger specific surface area of the Mg substitution sample. Moreover, the substitution of Al and Mg improves the electrochemical performances of LCO materials by reducing the initial discharge capacity while maintaining the long cycle life. Luo et al. [113] tried to enhance the thermal stability of LCO materials by Mg and Mn substitutions, see Fig. 16(b). In which, the additions of Mn and Mg help suppress the rapid exothermic reaction between the charged LiCo1 − z (MnMg) z/2O2 (z = 0.1, 0.2) and electrolytes. However, when z increases to 0.3, thermal runaway occurs for the cathode materials again. Similar phenomena also appear in the case of LiCo1 − z (NiMn) z/2O2, where the thermal stability of LiCo1 − z (NiMn) z/2O2 does not significantly improve with a further increase in the Ni and Mn concentration, z, in the transition-metal layer when z>0.2 [114]. Combining the results of Al addition, it can be concluded that Al substitutions may be more effective than Mn, Mg and Ni substitutions at improving the thermal stability of LCO cathode materials. The high efficiency of Al substitution at improving the thermal stability of cathode materials is also shown in NMC and LNO materials [109,115–117]. The impact of Al doping on the thermal stability of NMC111 was investigated by Zhou et al. [115] using an ARC instrument. Al substitution for Co in NMC111 caused a dramatic improvement in thermal stability compared to the material without Al. Fig. 16(c) illustrates the self-heating rate results for 94 mg of LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3 − z Al z O2 (z = 0–0.14) charged to 4.6 V reacting with 30 mg of 1 M LiPF6 EC:DEC electrolyte with starting temperatures of 70 and 180 °C. With the addition of Al, the reactivity between the NMC111 materials and electrolytes was dramatically restrained. Furthermore, the temperature rise caused by the exothermic reaction does not change appreciably with z, indicating that the total heat produced by the exothermic reaction between the charged NMC111 and electrolytes does not decrease much with z. In other words, the main impact of Al is a reduction in the rate of reactions. Fig. 16(d) shows the ARC results between LiNi0.95 M0.05O2 (M = Al, Mg, Mn, Co) and electrolytes at elevated temperatures. It is clear that the stability of Mg-, Al- and Mn-doped LNO materials is greatly improved in comparison with that in the absence of doping. Over the entire testing temperature ranges, thermal runaway does not occur for these samples. However, the doping of Co only brings about little effect on the thermal stability of LNO. Fig. 17 compares the thermal stability of the NMC series materials (NMC111, NMC442, NMC532, NMC622, NMC631, NMC721 and NMC811) and Li-rich materials by listing the temperatures when the self-heating rates of the samples reach 0.2 °C min−1. With the increasing the Ni content within NMC materials, the thermal stability of the materials is gradually decreased, especially for NMC811, which has a stability that is very poor. Mn ions dominate the thermal stability of NMC materials because they are not electrochemically active and may sustain the oxide matrix even in a highly delithiated state [118]. The quantity of released oxygen increases with the amount of Ni in delithiated NMC and decreases with the start temperature of the phases transitions to the spinel and rock-salt phases [65]. The solvent burns when the oxygen is released, creating heat. As a result, a higher Ni content and lower Co content often provide faster self-heating rates and lower exothermic reaction starting temperatures. However, it should be noted that NMC631 exhibits better safety than most NMC materials [119]. In addition, Li-rich materials demonstrate a much lower reactivity than NMC811, even if their specific capacity is much higher [120]. Both single-crystal NMC532 and NMC811 materials show a much better stability than the corresponding traditional NMC materials [63]. Therefore, the performance of single-crystal NMC materials is worthy of being noted in the future. 3.8 Summary of the investigation on the thermal stability of cathode materials The impact of the above-mentioned factors on the thermal stability of cathode materials investigated via ARC is summarized in Table 4 . Generally, cathode materials only encounter thermal hazards with the presence of electrolytes at elevated temperatures. The thermal runaway mechanism of cathode materials can be divided into two types: (1) for layered/spinel-structure cathode materials, decomposing and releasing oxygen at elevated temperatures is the root cause of thermal runaway, which could induce electrolyte combustion and severe thermal behaviors; (2) for olive-structure cathode materials, a phase change at elevated temperatures is the root cause of thermal runaway, which releases little heat and thereby the accompanied thermal behavior is comparatively gentler. As a result, the impact of those typical factors on cathode materials’ thermal stability usually differs in different cathode material systems. In particular, a more systematic investigation concerning the impact of electrolytes on the the thermal stability of cathode materials is required, the electrolyte systems with various lithium salts, solvents (carbonyl electrolyte, ether electrolyte, nitrile electrolyte, etc.), and additives with various functional groups are worthy of a more detailed exploration. 4 Investigation on the thermal stability of anode materials In the early 1960 s, lithium metal was used as the anode material for lithium primary cells. However, the poor safety of lithium-ion cells incorporating lithium metal inhibited their further application even though much effort had been expended. In the 1980 s, carbon material was first introduced for the anode materials, which has become the most common anode material in lithium-ion cells up until now. The theoretical specific capacity of carbon materials is about 372 mA h g−1. In the process of charging or discharging, lithium ions intercalate or deintercalate in the carbon materials to form a lithium carbon intercalation compound Li x C6. (17) Li x C 6 ↔ Li x - y C 6 + y Li + + y e - The earliest carbon materials are ungraphitized carbon materials, which can be further divided into graphitizable carbon and refractory carbon. This type of anode materials usually demonstrates characteristics like a disordered structure, low crystallinity, small grain size and large crystal plane distance. Additionally, disadvantages such as a high irreversible capacity and low potential limit the usage of ungraphitized carbon materials, and now they have been replaced by graphite. Compared with ungraphitized carbon materials, graphite has a better conductivity and higher crystallinity as well as a good layered structure; therefore, lithium ions are easier to intercalate or deintercalate. The reversible specific capacity of graphite can achieve 300 mA h g−1, which is near the theoretical capacity of Li x C6 (372 mA h g−1). Moreover, it matches well with most cathode materials, which enables it to be widely used in lithium-ion cells. Graphite consists of artificial graphite and natural graphite. Artificial graphite is made by graphitizing carbon using high temperatures. So far, mesocarbon microbead (MCMB) is the most common artificial graphite [121,122]. As for natural graphite, it is particularly suitable for lithium ions movement due to its high graphitization. Besides that, the voltage profile of natural graphite is flat and the cost is relatively low; therefore, natural graphite has always been the focus of the anode materials for lithium-ion cells. Nevertheless, graphite material is sensitive to electrolytes owing to its high graphitization crystallinity and highly oriented layered structure, so it must be used in the EC-based electrolytes. In addition, lithium and organic solvents can be inserted into the graphite layer and decompose during cycling, which may further cause the graphite layer to gradually peel off and the graphite particles to crack [123]. Thus, many methods have been proposed to improve the performance of graphite, including surface oxidation, doping, coating, carbon-silicon composite etc., [124–128]. In addition to carbon materials, there still exist some other candidates for the anode materials, such as the transition metal oxides (Li x Fe2O3, Li x WO2, Li x MoO2, Li x Nb2O5 , etc.), SnO2, lithium-containing transition metal nitrides (Li7MnN4, Li3 − x Co x N, etc.), sulfides (TiS, MoS2 , etc.) [129–132]. Furthermore, with the development of nanotechnology, nano-scale anode materials like carbon nanotubes and nanoalloys have been given much attention, which may enhance the specific capacity of anode materials to higher than 500 mA h g−1 [133–136]. 4.1 Effect of lithium content on the thermal stability of anode materials In contrast to the cathode materials, as the SOC increases, lithium ions removed from the cathode intercalate into the anode. That is, the larger the SOC, the greater the lithium content for the anode. To explore the effect of lithium content on the thermal stability of anode materials at elevated temperatures, Richard et al. [21] performed a series of tests on MCMB using an ARC instrument. Three different compositions (Li0.81C6, Li0.45C6 and Li0.25C6) were selected when MCMB was discharged to 0.0, 0.089 and 0.127 V, respectively. As shown in Fig. 18 (b), the self-heating rate curves can be divided into two regions at around 105 °C. There is a peak between 80 and 105 °C, which occurs at roughly the same intensity for all the samples. In other words, the exothermic behaviors in this range are independent of the lithium content. Richard et al. attributed the exothermic reactions between 80 and 105 °C to the decomposition of the metastable SEI layer at elevated temperatures. The mechanism might be (18) CH 2 OCO 2 Li 2 → Li 2 CO 3 + C 2 H 4 + CO 2 + 0 . 5 O 2 (19) Li 2 CO 3 + 2 Li → 2 Li 2 O + CO (20) CH 2 OCO 2 Li 2 + 2 Li → 2 Li 2 CO 3 + C 2 H 4 For these MCMB samples, there is roughly the same amount of the SEI layer, which brings about nearly the same exotherm. Once it is eventually depleted, the self-heating rate slows. Beyond 105 °C, the self-heating rate increases with the increasing lithium content. Therefore, the heat must come from the reactions that the intercalated lithium diffuses through the SEI layer to react with the solvents. When more lithium exists within MCMB, there is more heat that can be released. In the case of 0.127 V, the self-heating rate declines at approximately 175 °C, indicating the consumption of lithium. However, the electrolyte soon starts to decompose, leading to a re-rise in the self-heating rate. This hypothesis can be further confirmed by Fig. 18(c), where the case of 0.22 V is also shown. Due to the lack of intercalated lithium, the formation of the metastable SEI layer and the reactions between the lithium and solvents are restrained; finally, the produced heat of the sample is much less than that of the others. In summary, the thermal stability of MCMB declines with an increase in lithium content. Maleki et al. [64] conducted similar investigations on the mesocarbon microfiber (MCMF) anode materials, see Fig. 18(d). With an increase in SOC, i.e., the lithium content, the reactivity between MCMF and the electrolyte is greatly exacerbated, especially for the overcharge cases where the exotherm appears much earlier and the severity is also much worse. The differences among the 125%, 150% and 200% SOC samples were caused by lithium plating and the byproducts of overcharge. 4.2 Effect of particle size on the thermal stability of anode materials According to Section 3.2, the thermal stability of LCO, NCA and LNO cathode materials is gradually exacerbated by a decrease in particle size. A similar phenomenon is also revealed for the anode materials. By grinding MCMB powders, particles with a specific surface area of 6.9 m2 g−1 can be obtained, compared to 1.1 m2 g−1 before grinding. Fig. 19 (a) shows the ARC profiles of these two types of MCMB materials. Obviously, the MCMB samples with a higher surface area exhibit larger self-heating rates for all SOC conditions. The temperature rise caused by the peak is around 30 °C for the samples with high surface areas compared to 15 °C for those with low surface areas. As is known, particles with a larger surface area can form more SEI layers, which decomposes at elevated temperatures, therefore producing more heat and causing a severer temperature rise. In terms of the followed heat release, it is attributed to the intercalated lithium reacting with the solvent, based on the results of Section 4.1. It is obvious that the self-heating rate of the high-surface-area sample is also larger than that of the low-surface-area one during this process. Imagine the process develops as shown in Fig. 19(b) and (c), where two MCMB particles with radii of R and R/2 are included. To maintain the same quality of powder, the amount of particles for the high-surface-area sample should be eight times that of the low-surface-area sample. If the same volume of the SEI layer is formed on the surface of these two types of samples, it can be calculated that the thickness of the SEI layer for the high-surface-area particles is approximately half that of the low-surface-area ones. Hence, the movement of lithium across the layer is be faster for the high-surface-area materials, leading to more violent reactions and a higher self-heating rate. On the basis of Richard, MacNeil et al. [137] explored the thermal stability of six types of carbon anode materials (carbon fiber, and four artificial graphites, i.e., MCMB, KS-75, SFG-44, SFG-75 and XP-3 petroleum coke) in LiPF6 EC/DEC electrolyte, where the surface area increases were in order. Before the tests, all of them were discharged to 0.0 V. As shown in Fig. 20 (a), the KS-75, SFG-44, SFG-75 samples present a much more severe reactivity at elevated temperatures than the carbon fiber, MCMB and XP-3 petroleum coke samples. Except for XP-3 petroleum coke, the thermal stability of carbon materials declines as the surface area increases. The anomaly of XP-3 petroleum coke results from its surface, which is inaccessible to the electrolyte such that the reactions are restrained. The temperature rise during SEI layer decomposition and the initial self-heating rate at the beginning of the intercalated lithium reacting with electrolytes were extracted and are depicted in Fig. 20(b) and (c), respectively. The higher the surface area, the larger the temperature rise and the higher the initial self-heating rate are except for those of XP-3 petroleum coke. 4.3 Effect of electrolytes on the thermal stability of anode materials 4.3.1 Effect of lithium salt Based on Section 4.2, the SEI layer greatly impacts the thermal stability of carbon anode materials. The formation of SEI layers is dependent on the lithium salt and the solvent employed in the electrolyte; therefore, any variation in the lithium salt or solvent may change the thermal stability of carbon anode materials at elevated temperatures [138]. Richard et al. [21] measured the self-heating rate for MCMB samples in either LiPF6 EC:DEC (1:1) or LiBF4 EC:DEC (1:1), see Fig. 21 (a). Obviously, the MCMB samples in LiBF4 EC:DEC (1:1) do not exhibit a peak in the self-heating rate profiles, as shown in the LiPF6 EC:DEC (1:1) case. Moreover, the onset of the exotherm is found to occur earlier at around 50 °C as opposed to 70 °C for LiPF6 EC:DEC (1:1). According to Aurbach et al. [139], there were no alkyl-carbonates or other metastable components in the SEI layer that developed on the carbon in LiBF4-based electrolytes. Hence, it cannot demonstrate the exothermic peak due to the decomposition of metastable components. Instead, the heat produced by the LiBF4 sample must come from the interaction between the intercalated lithium and solvent, leading to an earlier onset of self-heating. Eventually, the activation energy of the MCMB samples in LiBF4 electrolyte is calculated as 0.65 eV, which is much smaller than that of LiPF6, 1.69 eV, indicating a worse stability of carbon anode materials in LiBF4 electrolytes. Similar results were also obtained in the work of Macneil et al. [20]. In contrast, the safety of carbon materials can be improved by LiBOB electrolyte. Fig. 21(b) compares the self-heating rate profiles of 100 mg of MCMB in 100 mg of LiPF6 EC:DEC and LiBOB EC:DEC, where the safety advantage of the LiBOB salt over LiPF6 in EC/DEC solvent for the lithiated MCMB anode materials is apparent. In other words, a more robust passivating film is formed on Li x C6 with the presence of LiBOB [140]. Moreover, the mixing of LiPF6 and LiBOB in EC/DEC solvent also shows a safety improvement [141]. As the LiBOB concentration increases, the temperature rise in the first peak gradually declines, suggesting the restrain of LiPF6 in reacting with Li x C6. Therefore, the choice of the lithium salt in the electrolyte is critical, and an equilibrium between both electrode materials should be considered. On the other hand, the amount of lithium salt also demonstrates a huge effect on the thermal stability of anode materials. Fig. 21(c) depicts the ARC profiles for 100 mg of MCMB in EC/DEC solvent with different LiPF6 concentrations. With an increase in LiPF6 concentration, it is obvious that the temperature rise induced by the exothermic peak aggravates. This is attributed to the fact that LiPF6 can react with intercalated lithium at elevated temperatures to form the SEI layer; moreover, the decomposition product of LiPF6, PF5, can react easily with organic solvents to release heat. Therefore, the temperature increase for the peak is roughly proportional to the concentration of LiPF6 in the solvent, that is, the addition of LiPF6 salt into the solvent initially decreases the thermal stability of carbon anode materials. As the reactions proceeds, it can be found that a lower self-heating rate is exhibited by the sample with a larger amount of LiPF6 salt. The products between the lithium and PF5 incorporate into the SEI layer to form a passivating film that effectively inhibits the reactivity between the intercalated lithium and solvent. Moreover, a larger amount of LiPF6 consumes more intercalated lithium such that there is less lithium remaining to react with the solvent. Hence, the self-heating rate declines. In a word, LiPF6 aggravates the reactivity of carbon anode materials during the first process, while it restrains their further reactions. 4.3.2 Effect of solvent To explore the effect of the solvent on the thermal stability of anode materials, Fig. 22 (a) demonstrates the self-heating rate profiles of 100 mg of MCMB reacting with 100 mg of different solvents: DMC, DEC, EC and EC/DEC (1:2). Among them, the carbon materials show the worst thermal stability in the DMC solvent with an obvious exotherm exhibited at around 90 °C. Besides that, carbon materials are also unstable in the DEC solvent where thermal runaway occurs. The results of EC and EC/DEC solvents reveal that EC can effectively improve the thermal stability of carbon materials at elevated temperatures. According to Aurbach et al. [138], the products between EC and lithium are more stable in the electrolyte which stabilizes the passivating film on Li x C6 and protects it from further reactions. In addition, the solvent ratio also influences the thermal stability of anode materials. As stated previously, the existence of EC improves the stability of carbon anode materials. Thus, increasing the ratio of EC in the electrolyte may be a way to stabilize carbon materials. Fig. 22(b) shows the self-heating rate profiles of MCMB samples in two electrolytes: 1 M LiPF6 EC:DEC (33:67) and 1 M LiPF6 EC:DEC (50:50). Apparently, the carbon materials show a better stability in the 1 M LiPF6 EC:DEC (50:50) electrolyte. Differing from the self-heating curve of 1 M LiPF6 EC:DEC (33:67), that of 1 M LiPF6 EC:DEC (50:50) shows a minor shoulder prior to the peak, which is the result of the metastable EC products. As for the main exothermic peak, it should be related to DEC. In the end, activation energies of 1.47 and 1.69 eV can be calculated corresponding to 1 M LiPF6 EC:DEC (33:67) and 1 M LiPF6 EC:DEC (50:50), respectively, suggesting that there is a better thermal stability for MCMB in electrolytes with a higher EC ratio. 4.3.3 Effect of additive On the basis of Section 3.4.3, additives of electrolytes do not have a strong impact on the safety of cathode materials, in comparison with those of lithium salt or solvent. Herein, the related contents about the anode materials are discussed. Contrary to the thermal stability of the cathode materials, additives bring about a much more significant effect on that of anode materials by impacting the formation of the SEI layer. Fig. 23 (a) compares the outcomes of ARC studies using 140 mg of lithiated graphite and 140 mg of electrolytes containing 2 wt% of selected additives (VC, PES, MMDS, DTD, TMS, PLS, TTSP and TTSPi) to those obtained using the control electrolyte. Except for PES, the other selected electrolyte additives successfully suppress the self-heating rate in comparison with the control sample over almost the entire temperature range. Among them, the addition of 2% MMDS restrains the exothermic peak at around 100 °C, namely, the decomposition of the metastable SEI on the lithiated graphite. This suggests that 2% MMDS is helpful to the formation of a thermally stable SEI layer on the graphite surface. In addition, the addition of 2% TTSPi dramatically decreases the self-heating rate from 150 to 200 °C compared to the control sample. Furthermore, a proper combination of several additives may bring a significant improvement to the thermal stability of the anode materials. As shown in Fig. 23(b), blends of 2% VC + 1% MMDS + 1% TTSPi and 2% PES + 1% MMDS + 1% TTSPi dramatically inhibit the decomposition of the metastable components of the SEI layer on the lithiated graphite at around 100 °C. Additionally, the self-heating rate of the samples is also lower than that of the control sample over nearly the entire temperature range. In addition, the concentration of additives in the electrolyte may also change the thermal stability of anode materials, see Fig. 23(c) where 2%, 5% and 10% VC are added into the electrolyte. As the VC concentration increases, it can be found that the exothermic peak around 100 °C is gradually restrained. Meanwhile, it also causes the aggravation of the self-heating rate after 130 °C for a sample with a high VC concentration. Similar phenomena are also shown in the case of FEC [93]. To conclude, the thermal stability of anode materials can be considerably enhanced by proper additives, with reasonable concentration and collocation. 4.4 Effect of binder on the thermal stability of anode materials As stated in Section 3.5, the effect of a binder on the thermal stability of cathode materials is relatively minor. Whereas, the binder could affect the formation of the SEI layer on the carbon. Therefore, it may bring a comparatively larger impact on the thermal stability of anode materials. It is necessary to reveal the reactivity of LixC6 with binders before investigating the effect of a binder on the thermal stability of anode materials. As shown in Fig. 24 (a), there is almost no heat released over the whole temperature range for the sample of Li x C6 with the 2% ethylene propylene diene terpolymer (EPDM) binder, with the absence of electrolytes. This means that Li x C6 does not react significantly with the EPDM binder in this temperature range. As for the sample mixed with the PVDF binder (Fig. 24b), the self-heating rate is exhibited from 250 to 300 °C due to the reaction between Li x C6 and the F within the PVDF binder. The mechanism is [143] (21) - - CH 2 - CF 2 - - n + n Li → n LiF + - - CH - CF - - n + 0.5 n H 2 However, the heat released by this reaction is relatively minor, in comparison with that from the reaction of Li x C6 with the LiPF6 EC/DEC electrolyte, which can be confirmed by Fig. 24(e), where the ARC profiles of MCMB containing various amounts of the PVDF binder (1%, 2%, 3.5%, 7% and 14%) with 1 M LiPF6 EC/DEC are demonstrated. The exothermic behaviors for these samples are almost consistent during the whole process. That is, PVDF does not significantly influence the reactivity between Li x C6 and the LiPF6 EC/DEC electrolyte. Although the exothermic behaviors between Li x C6 and the binder are not obvious, they may influence the reactivity of anode materials by affecting the SEI layer. In comparison with the PVDF binder, the EPDM binder is not plasticized with electrolytes; therefore, the solvent cannot diffuse through it to react with the intercalated lithium. Any lithium must travel through the SEI layer, so it can react with the solvent. In general, the SEI layer is thicker for the anode materials with an in-plasticized binder. This longer diffusion restricts the reaction that is responsible for the heat releasing after the peak as stated above; in the end, a lower self-heating rate for the sample comprising EPDM is demonstrated, see Fig. 25 . In summary, the traditional PVDF binder does not significantly affect the thermal stability of anode materials, while the EPDM binder may decrease the reactivity of anode materials due to its inflexibility to the electrolyte. 4.5 Effect of initial heating temperature on the thermal stability of anode materials As stated in Section 3.6, the initial heating temperature affects the profiles of the self-heating rate for a sample tested by an ARC instrument. This also fits in the case of anode materials. Fig. 26 depicts the self-heating rate curves for 0.0 V MCMB in LiPF6 EC:DEC (33:67) electrolyte with initial temperatures of 40, 80, 100, 110, 115, 130 and 150 °C. The self-heating rate increases if the MCMB samples are heated to a higher initial temperature, while the measured temperature rise declines. The exothermic reactions of these samples start at a fixed temperature, therefore less heat can be detected by the ARC instrument if a higher initial temperature is selected. In addition, there also exists an ‘Arrhenius line’ to fit the initial slope of the profiles for all the samples. The activation energy is further calculated as 1.38 eV for 0.0 V MCMB in LiPF6 EC:DEC (33:67). The universal ‘Arrhenius line’ also exists in the other anode materials, e.g., carbon fiber, MCMB, KS-75, SFG-44, SFG-75 and XP-3 petroleum coke. Activation energies can be calculated as 1.5, 1.4, 1.3, 1.5, 1.5 and 1.5 eV, respectively [137]. The similar activation energy indicates the consistent heat released by these samples. As discussed previously, the initial exothermic reactions come from the decomposition and formation of the SEI layer, so, consequently, the activation energy of this process is determined by the nature of SEI layers. The SEI layer should have the same chemistry for all carbon samples, with only the difference in the SEI amount since the SEI layer is dependent on the lithium salt and solvent that are utilized. 4.6 Thermal stability comparison of different anode materials As revealed in Section 4.2, the fiber and MCMB exhibit much better safety than the other carbon anode materials due to their larger particle size. Fiber even has a lower self-heating rate compared with MCMB, which leads to increased stability. The shortcoming of fiber should be its shape, which results in electrodes of low density. Fiber would be a good candidate for the anode materials of lithium-ion batteries if it could be packed more effectively. In addition, fiber appears to possess a relatively smoother surface among the carbon materials, which provides control over the fiber diameter during the manufacturing process. On the other hand, some promising alloy anode materials such as Li7Ti5O12 and Li0.5VO2 also exhibit better thermal stability over traditional graphite materials [67]. Fig. 27 (a) compares the self-heating rate profiles for Li0.81C6, Li7Ti5O12 and Li0.5VO2 when reacting with EC/DEC solvent at elevated temperatures. The onset temperatures of an exotherm for the three samples are 100, 130 and 230 °C, respectively and the corresponding heat generated is approximately 215, 110 and 54 kJ mol−1. The increased onset temperature and decreased heat that is released suggest that both Li7Ti5O12 and Li0.5VO2 have a much higher thermal stability than Li0.81C6. Moreover, there exists a linear relationship between material potential and generated heat, see Fig. 27(b). As the potential of anode materials increases, a smaller amount of heat during the reaction with EC/DEC solvent is produced. This reveals that if the potential of an anode material is higher than 3.3 V vs. Li, this material does not thermally react with EC/DEC solvent to release heat which may be instructive for the design of highly safe lithium-ion cells. Furthermore, Li7Ti5O12 and Li0.5VO2 also present much better safety than Li0.81C6 with the presence of lithium salt, as shown in Fig. 27(c). The reactions between Li7Ti5O12 or Li0.5VO2 and 1 M LiPF6 EC/DEC consist of three processes. The heat generated from 160 to 220 °C mainly results from the reaction between LiPF6 and intercalated lithium, followed by the solvent reacting with lithium between 220 and 260 °C. As for the last process, it should be the reaction between the generated metal oxide and solvent at elevated temperatures. The released heat during these three processes by Li7Ti5O12 and Li0.5VO2 is also smaller than that of Li0.81C6. Considering the excellent thermal stability and the high capacity of Li7Ti5O12 or Li0.5VO2 over Li0.81C6, it is promising for Li7Ti5O12 and Li0.5VO2 to replace traditional carbon anode materials if their defects such as a high cost, low output voltage etc., could be overcome in the future. Additionally, lithium may produce alloys that have substantially higher specific capacities than graphite when combined with metals like Si, Sn, Sb, and Al, for example Cu6Sn5, SnSb, LiSi and Sn30Co30C40 [146–150]. Moreover, the thermal stability of these alloys in the electrolyte is generally better than that of graphite. Fig. 27(d) compares the self-heating rate profiles for Li0.81C6, LiSi and lithiated Sn30Co30C40 in the presence of 1 M LiPF6 EC:DEC electrolytes. Obviously, both LiSi and lithiated Sn30Co30C40 show lower self-heating rates than the Li0.81C6 over the entire testing range. The self-heating rate of lithiated Sn30Co30C40 and LiSi is quite similar below 250 °C.
