After that, lithiated Sn30Co30C40 shows a lower reactivity than LiSi and the latter even occurs thermal runaway at around 285 °C. The excellent safety of Sn30Co30C40 is attributed to its much lower specific surface area of 0.60 m2 g−1, in comparison with that of Si and MCMB, i.e., 1.04 and 0.81 m2 g−1. In addition, Si can react with the electrolyte to form Li2SiO3 at elevated temperatures to release heat. Corresponding reactions do not occur in the case of Sn30Co30C40, which is due to the carbon matrix that surrounds the CoSn grains. As for the comparatively better safety of Si than graphite, it is the result of the thicker SEI layer on the surface of Si that slows the reaction with electrolytes [145]. 4.7 Summary of the investigation on the thermal stability of anode materials The impact of the above-mentioned factors on the thermal stability of anode materials investigated via ARC is summarized in Table 5 . Until now, carbon anode materials have been the most popular anode materials for lithium-ion cells; therefore, investigation on the thermal stability of anode materials almost always focuses on graphite. In general, the thermal runaway mechanism of carbon anode materials is attributed to the reactions between electrolytes and lithiated graphite which consist of three stages [151–154]: stage Ⅰ is associated with the decomposition of SEI layers; stage Ⅱ is associated with the reaction between lithiated graphite and electrolyte; stage iii is associated with the reaction between lithiated graphite and binder. To reveal the effect of typical factors on the thermal stability of anode materials, the corresponding effect of them on the three stages should be researched. With an increase in lithium content, the reaction between lithiated graphite and electrolytes would be worse. With a decline in particle size, more SEI layers could decompose and lithium could more easily escape further reaction with electrolytes. The effect of electrolytes on the thermal stability of anode materials is related to the SEI layer characteristics. A robust SEI layer could be formed by a proper electrolyte, which would help to suppress the reactions between electrolytes and lithiated graphite. A binder starts to participate in reactions until the thermal runaway proceeds to a later stage, meanwhile the amount of binder is minor; thereby, the traditional binder (PVDF) has little impact on the thermal stability of carbon anode materials which is identical to the cathode material’s result. 5 Investigation on the thermal stability of full cells 5.1 Correlation between ARC and DSC results and full cell safety When considering the importance of lithium-ion cell safety, cells must successfully satisfy a number of compulsory test standards, such as UN R100, SAE-J2464, IEC-62133 and GB/T 31,485 before any applications [155]. In which, some standard tests such as immersion, penetration, crush, overcharge, short-circuit and overheating etc., are usually included. The evaluation of cell safety requires quantities of cells and is time-consuming, therefore it brings a high cost for the manufacturers especially when the outcome is uncertain. If the safety performance of cells could be judged before test cells were produced, a lot of time and money could be saved. Only cells that show a strong possibility of passing the safety tests would be produced for testing. Using functions that describe the kinetics of the reactions in the cell and simple heat flow principles, a model could be constructed to predict how a cell made of certain materials behaves when exposed to abusive conditions without building the actual cell. Fortunately, the ARC profiles can be used to attain the initial values of the reaction kinetic parameters because the shape of the ARC profile is sensitive to changes in the kinetic parameters. Combining the thermal characteristics of cells from the literature, a predictive model can be built, and then the DSC profile can be used to verify this model, to see whether a correct exothermic behavior has been demonstrated. This was proven to be available by Hatchard et al. [24], who successfully applied their model to predict the response of cylindrical and prismatic lithium-ion cells to overheating tests without actually producing any cells. 5.2 Thermal stability of full cells during thermal runaway In addition to building the predictive model of full cell safety by measuring the exothermic profiles of cell components, ARC is also universally employed to explore the thermal stability of actual full cells. Different from the measurement in an ambient environment, an adiabatic environment can be formed by an ARC instrument. Hence, there is no heat lost to the surroundings during the experiment, instead all of the released reaction energy is used for the self-heating of lithium-ion cells. This helps remove the effect of heat exchange by air, so an accurate thermal behavior of the cell can be demonstrated. If we want to distinguish whether the cathode or anode side contributes to the thermal behaviors of full cells, the thermal stability results of individual cathode/anode materials, individual electrolytes, cathode/anode materials and electrolytes, cathode and anode materials as well as electrolytes, and full cells should be explored and then compared. Fig. 28 shows the representative schematic of a full-cell experiment using ARC. The cell is placed in the chamber with thermo-couples attached to measure the variation in surface temperatures. Meanwhile, the pressure inside the chamber can be monitored by a pressure sensor to illustrate the generation of gases. The cell can also be charged/discharged during the experiments by a cycle apparatus through electric wires. Once an experiment starts, the system is first heated to an initial temperature. When an equilibrium state is achieved, the system goes into the searching mode, so the exothermic reactions within the cell can be detected if the temperature rate exceeds the threshold (generally 0.02 °C min−1). The controller will change the heaters’ power when the cell enters the self-heating stage to maintain the same temperature in both the chamber and the sample cell, creating an adiabatic environment for the exothermic stage. Due to the limited space within the ARC chamber, the tests induced by overheating or overcharge are commonly conducted inside the ARC instrument to illustrate the thermal stability of full cells. Generally speaking, the thermal behavior of a cell during overheating initially proceeds slowly, but it accelerates exponentially as the temperature rises as a result of the thermal runaway. Fig. 29 shows the typical profiles of the cell surface temperature and voltage during overheating, which can be divided into several segments. At first, this is a process of searching exothermic reactions, thereby the temperature increases step by step. As the temperature ascends, the decomposition of the SEI layer encounters at around 90 °C [157]. The released heat pushes the sample to enter the self-heating segment. After that, the reactions between anode materials and electrolytes are provoked as a result of the breakdown of the SEI layer, which causes a stable increase in cell temperature and releases a lot of gases. At the meantime, the separator shrinks gradually under the high temperature leading to a minor short-circuit inside the cell, which is exhibited as the drop of voltage. As the gases accumulate, the safety valve opens to decrease the pressure which somewhat cools down the cell. Hereafter, the cathode materials and electrolytes start decomposing to release heat and generate oxygen. In the end, the combustion of organic electrolytes occurs and the flammable gases are also ignited to induce thermal runaway. The maximum temperature of thermal runaway ranges from 200 to 900 °C, depending on cell chemistry, capacity and SOC [158]. After that, it is a process of ARC cooling. With the help of ARC, the effects of cell chemistry, SOC, cell capacity and state of health (SOH) on the thermal stability of full cells can be investigated by analyzing several key parameters such as the onset temperature of self-heating (T o), the temperature when the safety valve opens (T sv), the temperature when thermal runaway occurs (T tr), the maximum temperature of samples during tests (T m), the maximum pressure inside the ARC chamber during tests (P m), the released heat of samples during tests (ΔH), the activation energy of samples (E a), etc. Fig. 30 (a) shows the data profiles of NMC532 cells with different SOCs during overheating. Obviously, the time from the cell starting to be heated to thermal runaway increases with the decreasing SOC. Besides that, larger values for the T m and the P m can also be obtained in the case of a higher SOC, revealing a larger amount of heat and gas released. In other words, the thermal stability of lithium-ion cells exacerbates with the increase of SOC and this is consistent with the results of electrode materials as stated in Sections 3.1 and 4.1. Similar conclusions were also proposed in some other studies [159–161]. By the way, the impact of cell capacity on safety resembles that of SOC. For a cell with a higher capacity (maintaining the same cell chemistry and SOC), both the stored energy and the amount of active materials within the cell would be more, which could induce more severe side reactions when the cell is exposed to abusive conditions, therefore worsening the cell reactivity [162]. In addition, the SOH also affects the thermal stability of lithium-ion cells. In general, a cell with a lower SOH exhibits a worse thermal stability. Fig. 30(b) shows theARC results of aged and fresh cells charged to 0%, 50% and 100% SOC. Regardless of the SOC, cells with 70% SOH present much lower values of T o and T tr, in comparison with cells with 100% SOH. The jelly roll is even ejected after tests for the aged cells, suggesting the much more severe thermal runaway behaviors. Although an aged cell usually stores less energy than a fresh one, it exhibits a worse thermal stability, which should be attributed to the variation in cell components after aging [166]. The decline of T o results from the growth of the metastable SEI layer during aging [167]. With regards to the decline of T tr, it may be associated with the decomposition of electrolytes and the generation of lithium plating during aging [163]. The degradation of cell components makes the cell be more reactive. Based on Sections 3.7 and 4.6, the chemistry of electrode materials greatly affects their thermal stability at elevated temperatures. Similarly, full cells composed of different chemistries also demonstrate various thermal behaviors under abusive conditions. Therefore, ARC devices are often used to reveal the safety of cells with different chemistries and analyze the effects of new materials on cell stability [160,165,168]. Fig. 30(c) shows theARC profiles of fully charged NMC111, LMO and LFP 18650-size cells. All three cells appear to be self-heating at about 90 °C, while the NMC111 and LMO cells achieve much larger values for T m (731 and 581 °C, respectively) compared with that of LFP, 259 °C. One reason for this is the difference among the capacities of the cells. Moreover, the self-heating rate of LFP is the lowest among these three materials, which is attributed not only to its lower capacity, but also to its much better thermal stability. Although the self-heating rates of NMC111 and LMO are almost in the same range, a higher T m is obtained in the case of NMC111, revealing a larger amount of heat that is released and worse safety. These reaction profiles suggest that cathode materials contribute significantly to the magnitude of the cell heat generation. Similar results are also exhibited in the work of Zaghib et al. [169]. On the other hand, the thermal runaway behaviors of full cells induced by overcharge can also be detected using ARC, which are comparatively different from those of overheating. The overcharge procedure starts when the ARC system reaches temperature equilibrium. The temperature step is set as 0 °C, so the calorimetry no longer heats the cell. In this way, the ARC instrument begins to track the cell surface temperature under adiabatic conditions. Fig. 31 (a) shows representative profiles of the cell voltage, surface temperature and internal resistance in the process of an overcharge. Similarly, it also consists of several stages from the beginning of overcharge to thermal runaway. From 100% to 120% SOC, the cell is slightly overcharged and there is no obvious side reaction inside the cell. As the overcharge proceeds, the over-potential of the cathode induces the oxidation of electrolytes [170]; meanwhile, metallic lithium begins to deposit on the anode surface after the anode is filled with intercalated lithium. The deposited lithium reacts with electrolytes to thicken the SEI layer, resulting in an increase in the internal resistance. These side reactions also release heat leading to a stable rise in the cell temperature. Further, the SEI layer breaks down when the temperature reaches 90 °C which aggravates the reactions between the lithiated anode and electrolyte, releasing massive heat. Moreover, the consumption of lithium in the anode causes a voltage drop [171]. Once the inner cell temperature reaches the shutdown temperature of the separator, a serious internal short-circuit occurs leading to violent reactions among the cathode, anode and electrolyte as well as the decomposition of the electrolyte. These reactions produce a great deal of heat and gases. Consequently, the cell ruptures as the inner pressure exceeds its limit, which is followed by thermal runaway. In summary, the over-potential heat and side-reaction heat during the overcharge process induce the cell thermal runaway. Additionally, the choice of current in the process of overcharge is found to significantly impact the thermal runaway behaviors. Fig. 31(b) shows the voltage and temperature profiles of cells overcharged with different rates, i.e., 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0 and 2.0 C (here, 1 C denotes a current equals to cell capacity). As expected, the increase in current exacerbates the occurrence of thermal runaway, with the time to thermal runaway getting shorter. The maximum cell voltage during overcharge also ascends linearly with the increasing current, which might be attributed to the serious polarization caused by the large current. In addition, SOCend denotes the final SOC when a cell is overcharged to failure and it symbolizes the cell’s tolerance to overcharge [173]. However, the SOCend declines gradually with an increasing current rate. That is, the thermal stability of a cell gets worse when it is overcharged at a larger current. 5.3 Difficulty modeling internal short-circuit with ARC results Referring back to Section 5.1, a predictive model could be built based on ARC results to predict the thermal behaviors of full cells under abusive conditions. Herein, the modeling of the internal short-circuit of a cell is presented. As is known, the self-heating of a cell in the low temperature range is dominated by the anode materials, whose initial self-heating rates can be fitted by an ‘Arrhenius line’. As a first approximation, the ‘Arrhenius line’ can be employed to predict if a cell would self-heat. When the ‘Arrhenius line’ is comparable to the heat loss curve, the maximum temperature to which the cell can be exposed to and remain stable can be determined. Fig. 32 (a) shows the ‘Arrhenius line’ and the heat loss curves under 20 and 60 °C ambient temperatures. For the case of 20 °C, it is apparent that the cell cannot self-heat unless a short-circuit causes the cell temperature to increase up to 143 °C. Regarding the 60 °C case, a cell does not self-heat unless the cell’s temperature is enhanced to 138 °C. The temperature of a short-circuited cell only rises if the amount of heat generated is greater than that lost through transfer or radiation to the environment. The generated heat is composed of ohm heat (Q o) and reaction heat (Q r). Since the initial reaction heat is mainly from the anode, then it can be expressed as [159] (22) Q r = h 1 C A 1 x f n e - E 1 / k T + h 2 C A 2 x i e - E 2 / k T e - z / z 0 where the two terms are for two separate reactions at the anode materials. h 1 and h 2 are the total quantities of heat that can be generated by each reaction per mass of reactant, C is the cell’s specific heat capacity, A 1 and A 2 are frequency factors, and E 1 and E 2 are activation energies. This provides the rate of heat generation per mass of anode materials. The parameters xf , xi , and z are functions of the type of carbon utilized and how it is charged. xf is the amount of the metastable SEI layer, xi is the quantity of the intercalated lithium within the carbon, and z is a dimensionless measure of the SEI thickness. Both the temperature changes and parameters changes are monitored, which are listed as follows. (23) d x f d t = - A 1 x f n e - E 1 kT (24) d x i d t = - A 2 x i e - z z 0 e - E 2 kT (25) d z d t = A 2 x i e - z z 0 e - E 2 kT As for the Q o, it is as (26) Q o = I 2 R where I is the average current during the short-circuit and R is the internal resistance of the cell. The heat loss (Q l) at an ambient temperature of 60 °C is as [21] (27) Q l = - 2.49666 + 0.02476 T + 0.00025 T 2 Therefore, the variation of cell temperature short-circuited under 60 °C is (28) d T = Q Cm d t where, Q = Q o + Q r−Q l, Cm is the cell’s heat capacity. The modeled results are shown in Fig. 32(b), where the measured result is also depicted. As can be seen, the cell temperature rapidly reaches the separator melting point (130 °C), and then it declines gradually due to the disappearance of Q o since there is no current after separator melting. The maximum temperature obtained by modeling is relatively higher than the experimental result, which is attributed to the fact that the modeling predicted the internal temperature of this cell, while the experiment measured the surface temperature. 6 Summary and outlook With the transition in the global energy policy from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources, lithium-ion cells, as promising energy storage devices exhibit superiority over many other types of energy devices and thus have been given considerable focus. Whereas, the safety concerns regarding lithium-ion cells are still the main obstacle that hinders large-scale applications of lithium-ion cells in many fields. Therefore, a cell with good electrochemical performances as well as convincing safety should be of great importance. To date, there has been plenty of work conducted to research the thermal stability of lithium-ion cells, ranging from individual cell components to component mixtures, full cells and battery packs. Among them, quantities of investigations have been carried out with the help of ARC due to its advantages over other types of thermal calorimetry. Hence, the effects of some significant factors including the lithium content, particle size, material density, lithium salt, solvent, additive, binder and initial heating temperature on the thermal stability of electrode materials have been reported. Generally speaking, cathode materials with a lower lithium content exhibit a worse thermal stability, which is contrary to the anode materials. Nevertheless, the effects of particle size and electrolyte (i.e., lithium salt, solvent and additive) are much more complicated, which differs with changes in the reaction system. Compared with cathode materials, the binder brings a somewhat greater impact on the thermal stability of anode materials, by affecting the formation of the SEI layer on the anode surface. Moreover, it is interesting to find that there exists an ‘Arrhenius line’ for the self-heating profiles of electrode materials with various initial heating temperatures, which can be used to predict the thermal behaviors of materials and even full cells. In addition, the thermal stability of some existing cathode materials has been compared, suggesting that the presence of Mn and polyanion can significantly enhance the thermal stability of cathode materials, and the doping of Al is also helpful to restrain the reactivity of materials. Regarding the anode materials, some alloy materials demonstrate much better safety than traditional carbon anode materials, except for their high capacity. On the other hand, the ARC is also widely used by manufacturers and researchers to determine the thermal stability of full cells under abusive conditions such as overheating and overcharge. Furthermore, reaction kinetic modelings can be built on the basis of ARC profiles, to predict the thermal behaviors of cell components and cells. Although great work has been done to reveal the safety features of lithium-ion cells with the aid of ARC, most of this work only focused on the temperature profiles of samples at elevated temperatures such as temperature vs. time and/or temperature rise rate vs. temperature. The pressure evolution along with testing inside the ARC chamber is seldom reported even though an ARC instrument can realize it easily. Considering the serious pressure shock of cells during thermal runaway especially in constrained spaces, it is of great importance to illustrate the pressure variation results of samples from ARC tests in addition to temperatures such that a more comprehensive evaluation of cell safety can be achieved. In virtue of the fast development of lithium-ion cells, there still remains a lot of work to illustrate the thermal stability of new electrode materials, new lithium salts, new solvents, new additives etc., so a full cell with advanced safety can be proposed. Whereby, how the decomposition of lithium salt, the unsaturated vapor pressure of solvents and the functional group of additives affect the system safety should be considered as well. The safety performance of these newly proposed cells and/or packs should be accordingly evaluated from both the commercial application and fundamental research levels. In addition, more efforts should be made to improve the accuracy of the ARC-result based predicting model; therefore, more comprehensive reaction mechanisms of cell materials should be revealed and a method to accurately determine the amount of the SEI layer must be developed. Also, some behaviors during the thermal runaway of actual cells such as safety valving, electrolyte evaporation etc., should be included in the model. Consequently, it should be noted that even though the ARC possesses many unique advantages over other calorimeter, synergetic approaches among the ARC with other devices like gas chromatography-mass spectrometry,Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy, in-situ X-ray diffraction, etc., should be employed to unveil the root mechanism behind the safety features. Dongxu Ouyang received his doctor degree in 2021 at the State Key Laboratory of Fire Science, University of Science and Technology of China, and is currently working at Nanjing Tech University. His research interests focus on lithium-ion battery safety evaluation, thermal management, and high-voltage electrolyte. Mingyi Chen received his doctor degree in 2017 at the State Key Laboratory of Fire Science, University of Science and Technology of China, and is currently an associate professor at Jiangsu University. His research interests focus on lithium-ion battery safety evaluation, fire research, and phase change materials. Jingwen Weng is currently pursuing her Ph.D. at the University of Science and Technology of China and Hongkong City University. Her research interests focus on lithium-ion battery thermal management, lithium-ion battery safety, and fire research. Kuo Wang obtained his master degree at Nanjing Tech University, and is currently pursuing his Ph.D. at the Beijing Institute of Technology. His research interests focus on lithium-ion battery fire suppression, and high-voltage electrolyte. Jian Wang received his doctor degree in 2000 at the University of Science and Technology of China, and had become a professor there since 2006. He is now a member of Fire Investigation Sub-Technical Committee of National Fire Protection Standardization Technical Committee of China. His research interests focus on lithium-ion battery safety evaluation, combustion mechanism under low-pressure environment, computer simulation and simulation of combustion process, aviation fire safety theory and prevention technology, highland fire prevention and control technology, and building performance fire design. Zhirong Wang is the winner of China Youth Science and Technology Award, leader of Jiangsu Excellent Science and Technology Innovation Team and Jiangsu Six Talent Summit Innovation Team, has been working at Nanjing Tech University since 2005. From 2013 to 2014, he was a visiting professor at the University of Maryland, College Park, USA. His research interests include fire and explosion prevention and control, hazardous chemical safety, safety management engineering, urban and industrial safety, chemical safety, fire safety, etc.

coredata.dc:description: Given the importance of lithium-ion cell safety, a comprehensive review on the thermal stability of lithium-ion cells investigated by accelerating rate calorimetry (ARC), is provided in the present work. The operating mechanism of ARC is discussed first, including the usage and the reaction kinetics. Besides that, the thermal stability of the cathode/anode materials at elevated temperatures is revealed by examining the impacts of some significant factors, i.e., the lithium content, particle size, material density, lithium salt, solvent, additive, binder and initial heating temperature. A comparison of the common cathode materials indicates that the presence of Mn and polyanion could significantly enhance the thermal stability of cathode materials, while the doping of Al also helps to restrain the reactivity. Except for their high capacity, some alloy materials demonstrate more competitive safety than traditional carbon anode materials. Furthermore, the thermal behaviors of full cells under abusive conditions are reviewed here. Due to the sensitivity of ARC to the kinetic parameters, a reaction kinetic modeling can be built on the basis of ARC profiles, to predict the thermal behaviors of cell components and cells. Herein, a short-circuit modeling is exampled.

coredata.dc:title: Exploring the thermal stability of lithium-ion cells via accelerating rate calorimetry: A review
